The age relationship of children in a family is expressed by a special set of words, which are used as proper nouns and terms of address, and also as adjectives. jethā (eldest brother), māhilā (second eldest), sãhĩlā (third eldest), kānchā (youngest).[footnote1] The corresponding terms for sisters are, jethī, māhilī, sãhĩlī, kānchī. [footnote1]:There are further terms in the set. ND lists eleven degrees s.v. jeṭho. Hill speakers prefer the forms ending in -o to those given above.
